input_sentence: If ego vehicle wants to overtake the other vehicle then it should use turn signals beforehand for t seconds.

temporal_relations.description: Turn signals must be active for t seconds before overtaking

metric_constraints.description: Turn signal must be active within the past t seconds before overtaking

stage_results.agent_response:
Reasoning Process:
- Step 1: Parse the objects list to build the ID→name mapping:
  - "obj_ego" → "ego"
  - "obj_other" → "other"
- Step 2: For each atomic proposition:
  - ap_1: predicate = "overtake", object = "obj_ego" ("ego"), related_object = "obj_other" ("other") → overtake(ego,other)
  - ap_2: predicate = "turn_signal", object = "obj_ego" ("ego") → turn_signal(ego)
- Step 3: Analyze temporal relations and metric constraints:
  - "Turn signals must be active for t seconds before overtaking" → Past-time requirement: turn_signal must have been active within [0,t] seconds in the past when overtake(ego,other) occurs.
- Step 4: Construct MTL formula using "P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego))" as a precondition for "overtake(ego,other)", applying the global property ("Always") with the G operator.
- Step 5: Assemble the final formula: G(overtake(ego,other) -> P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego)))

Final MTL Formula:
G(overtake(ego,other) -> P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego)))

synthesis_result.synthesis_reasoning:
- Step 1: Parse the objects list to build the ID→name mapping:
  - "obj_ego" → "ego"
  - "obj_other" → "other"
- Step 2: For each atomic proposition:
  - ap_1: predicate = "overtake", object = "obj_ego" ("ego"), related_object = "obj_other" ("other") → overtake(ego,other)
  - ap_2: predicate = "turn_signal", object = "obj_ego" ("ego") → turn_signal(ego)
- Step 3: Analyze temporal relations and metric constraints:
  - "Turn signals must be active for t seconds before overtaking" → Past-time requirement: turn_signal must have been active within [0,t] seconds in the past when overtake(ego,other) occurs.
- Step 4: Construct MTL formula using "P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego))" as a precondition for "overtake(ego,other)", applying the global property ("Always") with the G operator.
- Step 5: Assemble the final formula: G(overtake(ego,other) -> P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego)))

stage_results.agent_response:
Reasoning Process:
- The formula is `G(overtake(ego,other) -> P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego)))`.
- `G(...)` means "Always" or "at all times".
- `overtake(ego,other)` translates to "ego vehicle overtakes another vehicle".
- The implication `->` means "if ... then ...".
- `P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego))` means "ego vehicle used turn signals at some point within the previous t seconds".
- So, the whole formula states: "At all times, if the ego vehicle overtakes another vehicle, then the ego vehicle must have used turn signals within the previous t seconds."

Natural Language Translation:
Always, if the ego vehicle overtakes another vehicle, then the ego vehicle must have used turn signals within the previous t seconds.

verification_result.back_translation: Always, if the ego vehicle overtakes another vehicle, then the ego vehicle must have used turn signals within the previous t seconds.
verification_result.verification_reasoning:
- The formula is `G(overtake(ego,other) -> P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego)))`.
- `G(...)` means "Always" or "at all times".
- `overtake(ego,other)` translates to "ego vehicle overtakes another vehicle".
- The implication `->` means "if ... then ...".
- `P_[0,t](turn_signal(ego))` means "ego vehicle used turn signals at some point within the previous t seconds".
- So, the whole formula states: "At all times, if the ego vehicle overtakes another vehicle, then the ego vehicle must have used turn signals within the previous t seconds."

analyst.name: Analyst_Agent
analyst.description: Responsible for deconstructing natural language into structured semantic components

synthesizer.name: Synthesizer_Agent
synthesizer.description: Responsible for synthesizing syntactically correct MTL formulas from semantic components

verifier.name: Verifier_Agent
verifier.description: Responsible for verifying the semantic correctness of MTL formulas through back-translation
